me.wobblyyyy.pathfinder2.geometry

Class SlopeIntercept

  • java.lang.Object
    • me.wobblyyyy.pathfinder2.geometry.SlopeIntercept
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, LinearEquation
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    PointSlope

    public class SlopeIntercept
extends java.lang.Object
implements LinearEquation
    The most simple implementation of the LinearEquation interface, the SlopeIntercept form is a classic I'm sure you've heard of before. y = mx + b
    Since:
    0.1.0
    Author:
    Colin Robertson
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

        public PointXY getPoint()

        The line's "point" can be any point along the line.

      • getIntercept

        public double getIntercept()
        Get the equation's intercept with the Y axis.

        LinearEquation.getY(double) with an input of 0 returns the same number as this method.

        Specified by:
        getIntercept in interface LinearEquation
        Returns:

      • isVertical

        public boolean isVertical()
        Is the line vertical, meaning it has a slope of +- infinity?
        Specified by:

      • getVertical

        public double getVertical()
        Description copied from interface: LinearEquation
        If the line is vertical, get the line's X position.

        If the line is not vertical, return 0.0.

        Specified by:
        getVertical in interface LinearEquation
        Returns:
        the line's X position.

      • getIntersection

        public PointXY getIntersection(LinearEquation equation)
        Get the point of intersection between this equation and another LinearEquation. If the lines do not intersect (say, for example, they're parallel lines) this method should return null. This method does not take into account domain or range - any intersection between the two lines is considered valid and will be returned.
        Specified by:
        getIntersection in interface LinearEquation
        Parameters:
        equation - the other equation.
        Returns:
        the point of intersection between the two equations. If the equations do not intersect (if they have parallel slopes) this method will return null instead of a point.

      • intersectsWith

        public boolean intersectsWith(LinearEquation equation)
        Check if two equations intersect. This should, generally, always return true unless the equations are parallel.
        Specified by:
        intersectsWith in interface LinearEquation
        Parameters:
        equation - the equation to test.
        Returns:
        if the equations intersect, true. Otherwise, false.
